Award.AwardTitle: Blind Noise Estimation Using Signal Statistics in Random Band-Pass Domains

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Noise, which corresponds to random variations extrinsic to the signals of interest, is an ubiquitous aspect that affects the performance of many tasks in signal processing. Even with the improving quality and sophistication of the modern acquisition devices, digital signals still carry noise due to many incontrollable factors. This research focuses on the fundamental problem of estimating parameters of the random noise model directly from a noise corrupted signal. As an immediate consequence, the results of this investigation will be applicable in a wide range of fields, including the forensic analysis of digital images, automatic processing of medical images, spectrum sensing in wireless communications and data processing in sensory neuroscience.

The technical approach taken in this research exploits the regular statistical properties of the original signals in multiple signal representations and their relationship with the noise parameters. Specifically, we will investigate the use of domains constructed from random band-pass filters that are more effective in revealing ?typical? statistical properties of the signals, especially when compared with deterministic representations such as Fourier, DCT, and wavelet. Concurrently, we will investigate the mathematical relationship between the observed statistics of noisy signal and the noise parameters. Drawing on these theoretical findings, this research is expected to lead to more effective and efficient algorithms for blind noise estimation. More generally, the proposed work will also explore efficient algorithms for blind local noise estimation in the presence of non-stationary noise statistics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Noise, which corresponds to the stochastic variations extrinsic to the signals of interest, is a ubiquitous aspect in signal processing. The objective of blind noise estimation is to obtain parameters in the stochastic models of noise with only the availability of the noise corrupted signals. When applied to noise with spatially or temporally varying statistics, the determination of the inhomogeneous noise model parameters is referred to as blind local noise estimation. As noise affects the performances of many signal processing tasks, blind (local) noise estimation is a problem of wide theoretical interest and significant practical importance.

The objective of the proposed work is to develop novel theoretical and algorithmic frameworks for blind (local) noise estimation. The theoretical foundation of the proposed work is a study of the regular statistical properties of signals of practical interests (e.g., natural image and audio signals in band-pass domains, wireless data streams, and neural spike trains). Based on the relationship between signal statistics and noise characteristics in a noise corrupted signal, the algorithmic aspect of the proposed work draws on the theoretical findings to develop effective and efficient algorithms for blind noise estimation, and further extend the resulting algorithm for efficient blind local noise estimation. 

One particular application field of the proposed work with increasing social impact is digital image forensics. Photographs have long been regarded as reliable records of events, but their trustfulness are eroded by the ease of digital manipulation, enabled by the technology sophistication of image editing tools (e.g., Photoshop). Recent years have witnessed an increasing number of incidents with forgery images causing serious financial, legal, or political consequences. Correspondingly, the research field of digital image forensics, the objective of which is to ensure image authenticity and detect forgeries, has also undergone rapid development. 

We have studied the use of local noise statistics in detecting splicing forgeries, as most digital images contain noise introduced either during acquisition (e.g., sensor or quantization noise) or subsequent processing (e.g., compression). For an un-tampered natural image, one may expect that the noise levels across different regions typically differ only slightly. In particular, a composite image with regions from images with different intrinsic noise characteristics may exhibit inconsistencies in the local noise variances, which becomes a telltale evidence of tampering. We show that such inconsistencies can be effectively revealed after applying a preliminary version of the blind local noise variance estimation algorithm.
